questions.question_text: Which of the following commands would allow a penetration tester to access a private network from the Internet in Metasploit?

comments.content: It will be socks4a that will create a session through the internet. (the question says access the network.) It will not be autoroute because that will help you pivot to another computer in the network. Meaning you are already in.
Don't think this is right. Probably A is correct. - https://github.com/rapid7/metasploit-framework/blob/master/documentation/modules/auxiliary/server/socks4a.md

discussion.content:
PenTest+ Practice Tests Book - SYBEX

D. Metasploit is a tool for the development of exploits and the testing of them on live targets. The socks4a auxiliary is a module from within the framework. This auxiliary module provides a proxy server that uses Metasploit Framework routing to relay connections. So, using the use auxiliary/server/socks4a module allows a tester to access a private network from the Internet.

Once you got access to a perimeter box that has 2 NIC (1 for internal network and 1 for inet), you'll use 
B. run autoroute -s 192.168.1.0/24 in order to ACCESS the internal network. 
Once you got access using 'autoroute' you can use
D. use auxiliary/server/socks4a in order to run post modules in meterpreter
Therefore, first you'll need B to access, and after D to enumerate, run scripts....
Answer B. run autoroute -s 192.168.1.0/24
https://www.ivoidwarranties.tech/posts/pentesting-tuts/pivoting/meterpreter/

Selected Answer: B
looks good to me
RHOST is just defining the remote host outside your local network. Run autorun actually performs the execution of accessing the private network.
It was on the exam

I would go with B: 

Preparing to pivot across a network requires us to first establish a Meterpreter session on the victim machine. From there, we can use the autoroute script to enable access to the non-routable subnet:
meterpreter > run autoroute -s 10.0.0.0/24

Note: An non-routable address is a private network address. 

Non-routable: https://docs.actian.com/dataconnect/11.1/index.html#page/User/Non-routable_Addresses.htm

Sorry, I missed a source for the autoroute script:

Yup, I believe you are correct sir! The link you provided actually gives the answer. :)

Agree with you. "Preparing to pivot across a network requires us to first establish a Meterpreter session on the victim machine. From there, we can use the autoroute script to enable access to the non-routable subnet" - https://github.com/rapid7/metasploit-framework/blob/master/documentation/modules/auxiliary/server/socks4a.md 

run autoroute -s 192.168.1.0/24 - Add a route to 192.168.1.0/24 (establish a Meterpreter session on the victim machine - https://www.offensive-security.com/metasploit-unleashed/Pivoting/

use auxiliary/server/socks4a - Setup and run a socks proxy over meterpreter, this module provides a socks4a proxy server that uses the builtin Metasploit routing to relay connections. - https://www.offensive-security.com/metasploit-unleashed/proxytunnels/
https://nullsweep.com/pivot-cheatsheet-for-pentesters/

set rhost 192.168.1.10 - Set the target address

db_nmap -iL /tmp/privatehosts.txt - Use nmap and place results in database

Maybe: B. run autoroute -s 192.168.1.0/24 ?

questions.question_text: A client requests that a penetration tester emulate a help desk technician who was recently laid off. Which of the following BEST describes the abilities of the threat actor?

discussion.content: No way this is APT. Help desk tech does not have the skillset to be APT. Only other answer could be insider threat, but that's not listed. Answer is definitely B.

Selected Answer: B
looks good to me
I would go with Script Kiddie.
It was on the exam

comments.content: No political end goal therefore not a hacktivist.

discussion.content: Surely it would be Hacktivist since we dont know the skill level of the employee. They will however be emulating someone doing it for a cause (granted not a very good one) which is similar to a Hacktivist
As no Insider option, has to be B
No way this is script kiddie. Man, I really hope I won't encounter these nonsense questions during the actual exam....
I agree. I believe the correct answer is B.

A help desk technician is the best candidate to become a script kiddie.
B. Script kiddie
In kaplan they explain that you are emulating an employee that is more likely to use free hacking tools online making him an script kiddie.

I would go with B. APTs are very well funded programs, usually by nation-state actors or very well funded organized crime units. Put simply, money isn't an issue with APTs. They are usually in the espionage business or more sophisticated crimes. This question seem to be leading to a more low-level pentest job (Script Kiddie or social engineering). I would not go for hacktivists either because these campaigns engage more in political/social campaigns.

comments.content: You may be right. The client would hire a penetration tester to imitate/pretend to be an IT Tech who just got temporary or permanent laid off (not fired) to regain access to the network. This would show how prepared are the staff under this circumstance. Also, this wouldn't need any high tech skills like APT or organized crime has in order to breach this security.

discussion.content: I would prefer option-c.Hactivist, as the pentester is hired to emulate as help desk technician

comments.content: But a hacktivistâ€™s attacks are usually politically or socially motivated. An organized crime threat actor is a group of cybercriminals whose goal is financial gain. Script Kiddies usually lack the technical sophistication to mount an attack using their own tools. The best answer for me would be malicious insider as they are motivated by revenge (like in this scenario) or financial gain but, since this is not an option, I would stick with APT as you can remain undetected in the system for a long time without being detected, as you are impersonating a laid-off tech.

Agree. I think the best answer would be Malicious Insider but maybe they didn't want to make it too obvious they considered this an APT, as when you emulate a recently laid off employee you can have/gain access to the network and remains there undetected for an extended
period of time.
you have no idea what apt is

discussion.content: Mr Robot is correct. The Key is that the pentester has been asked to enumerate a help desk technician. Employees who attack systems are either Insider threats / apt's because of their ability to constantly be able to attack the system should they choose

It does not seem to me that the reference, cited in the answer, addresses the question asked. There is no disgruntled employee here.
https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/computer-science/disgruntled-employee

PenTest+ Practice Tests Book - SYBEX

A. Advanced persistent threat (APT) is a computer network attack in which a person or group gains unauthorized access to a network and remains undetected for an extended period of time. APTs provide the highest level of threat on the adversary tier list. Many of the techniques used by advanced persistent threat actors are useful for penetration testers, and vice versa. If your persistence techniques arenâ€™t monitored for or detected by the clientâ€™s systems, the findings should include information that can help them design around this potential problem.

questions.question_text: A penetration tester wants to target NETBIOS name service. Which of the following is the MOST likely command to exploit the NETBIOS name service?

discussion.content: C&D is correct. that sybex book is not good.

comments.content: how would blacklisting be easier? Whitelisting will go explicit allow, giving you the option for implicit deny; thus preventing unauthorized commands

I dissagree ...
The Quetions states: low-effort, short-term solutions to minimize the SQL
So i think it's C
and E. Because the blacklist approach isn't perfect but much easier to implement then a whitelist aproach.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
looks good to me
It was on the exam

PenTest+ Practice Tests Book

D and E. - Given this scenario, the client will want to use a blacklist and whitelist validation for the SQL statements. SQL injection is a common attack route that uses malicious SQL code for backend database manipulation to access information that was not intended to be displayed. SQL injections are one of the most common web hacking techniques. Blacklist validation tests the external input against a set of known malicious inputs. Whitelist validation tests an external input against a set of known, approved input. With whitelist input validation, the application knows exactly what is wanted and rejects other input.

comments.content:
Does it make sense to use a blacklist, if you are already using a whitelist? With a whitelist, you already know that every input is acceptable. 
The problem with a whitelist is: you have to be able to anticipate anything that will be input. So if you are asking for a name and address for a new user, you might run into trouble.

Conversely the problem with a blacklist is new networks may show up and need to be added in. Take the same approach you do with NTFS permissions: allow only that which is needed and very rarely deny access.

Researching further on this one, I believe C and D would be correct:

"Within an application itself, there are two approaches to input validation that can defend against SQL injection attacks: blacklisting and whitelisting. With blacklisting, specific, known malicious characters are removed from or replaced in user input. Although this approach is often implemented, largely due to the ease at which it can be accomplished, it is not effective when compared to whitelisting. Blacklisting can fail to properly handle complex obfuscation, which could allow an attacker to subvert filters and potentially inject SQL statements. This failure often occurs as a result of evolving attack techniques and filters that are not comprehensive or not implemented correctly."

https://tools.cisco.com/security/center/resources/sql_injection#8
https://www.synopsys.com/glossary/what-is-sql-injection.html
https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/SQL_Injection_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet.html
https://owasp.org/www-community/attacks/SQL_Injection

choices.F: Identify the source of malicious input and block the IP address.
choices.C: Identify and sanitize all user inputs.
choices.E: Use a blacklist approach for SQL statements.
choices.D: Use a whitelist approach for SQL statements.
choices.A: Identity and eliminate inline SQL statements from the code.
choices.B: Identify and eliminate dynamic SQL from stored procedures.

questions.question_text: A recently concluded penetration test revealed that a legacy web application is vulnerable to SQL injection. Research indicates that completely remediating the vulnerability would require an architectural change, and the stakeholders are not in a position to risk the availability on the application. Under such circumstances, which of the following controls are low-effort, short-term solutions to minimize the SQL injection risk? (Choose two.)
